title: Seeing requests timeout using Alchemy provider in forked mode. Alchemy reports no issues.

### Describe the bug

Hey again. So my original setBalance issue #2646  seems to be fixed, but I'm still seeing some timeouts which eventually lead to the Anvil node crashing.

[ethereum-mainnet.log](https://github.com/foundry-rs/foundry/files/9330728/ethereum-mainnet.log)

Our alchemy dashboards don't show any requests explicitly timing out or failing, so it's quite strange.

Questions I have:
Should timeouts crash the node? 
Is there a way to specify the number of retries? 
Does the timeout already take into account retries?

> Should timeouts crash the node?

Probably, albeit a bit more gracefully. The reason we want to fail in this state is that it could otherwise lead to invalid state silently, which would *then* lead to very very hard to reproduce/fix bug reports

Do you think the timeout might be on your end? I.e. Alchemy is not timing out but your connection is flaky or something like that. Anvil might be sending too many requests too quickly

@onbjerg We aren't seeing the same issues with Hardhat so I think it's an Anvil issue, no? I don't think our connection would be flaky. It's totally possible that Anvil would be sending in too many requests as we have a good number of parallel workers in our tests leading to sending in RPC requests. However, yeah we're running the same exact environment and test suite between Hardhat and Anvil and Hardhat doesn't seem to have these issues as frequently.

> source: TimedOut

this is a http request timed out error that is thrown when the HTTP request does not finish in a certain amount of time, it's configured to 120secs by default which usually should be more than sufficient.

this is for individual HTTP requests. if a request times out it would make sense that they don't appear in the dashboard because they're not processed?

this is definitely unrelated to retries etc because this happens directly in reqwest

https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/blob/61474f422caa6f9f843ae3a5bf656b5b3f507241/src/async_impl/client.rs#L1874

so the request is either not sent at all or alchemy drops it and doesn't send a response?

we could just remove the timeout but then it would hang indefinitely in such circumstances

Are there any config options/environment variables I can set that might help debug this?

Or, an option to just drop the request and ignore it after a certain threshold?

I don't think dropping the request and ignoring it is preferable since it would just silently lead to incorrect state as mentioned in my first comment, so I don't think adding support for that makes a lot of sense. It's much more preferable that we figure out what the underlying cause is

This issue from hardhat seems a little bit similar: https://github.com/NomicFoundation/hardhat/issues/2672#issue-1227453780. 

I'm trying to find a repro in this thread that would also cause a timeout on the Anvil node.

@onbjerg Yeah, I do think a solution instead of ignoring it would be to at least be able to config the timeout parameters. Hardhat lets you do that in their config (linked in the issue above), and it does seem to help people out with that specific issue.

hey @sunwrobert 

I've added a quick debug pr #2816 that allows you to manually set the req time out quick and dirty via `REQ_TIMEOUT` env var which expects milliseconds

```console
REQ_TIMEOUT=100000 anvil -f https://eth-mainnet.alchemyapi.io/v2/...                                                                                             
using 100s request timeout
```

the default timeout is `120s`

you should be able to install the branch via `foundryup --pr 2816`

Thanks, will try and post back

@onbjerg You mentioned this earlier about needing to install the proper build tools, which I believe I have, but our Dockerfile still doesn't build properly when installing from a specific branch (never finishes, just hangs). 

This is what our Dockerfile looks like:

```
FROM node:16.15.0-bullseye-slim

# Git needed for foundryup
RUN apt update && apt install -y curl && apt install -y git && apt install -y build-essential && \
    apt autoremove -y && \
    rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/* && \
    rm -rf /root/.cache

# Install rust toolchain
RUN curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | bash -s -- -y
ENV PATH="/root/.cargo/bin:${PATH}"

# Install foundryup
RUN curl -fsSL https://foundry.paradigm.xyz | bash
ENV PATH="/root/.foundry/bin:${PATH}"

# Install anvil
# TODO: Temp branch
RUN foundryup --pr 2816

COPY package.json package-lock.json  ./

RUN npm ci
COPY . ./
# Used by hardhat node
RUN mkdir -p cache
RUN chown node cache
ENV NODE_ENV production
ENTRYPOINT [ "./scripts/entrypoint_anvil.sh" ]
```

adding retries for timed out request should fix this I hope, will add this today
@sunwrobert timed out request should now be retried as well

@mattsse Results generally look better (a lot more tests passing!). One last request if possible. Any way for us to also do the original solution of 

1. specifying the timeout seconds 
2. maybe specifying number of retries (not as important).

I think being able to specify the timeout would be useful in general. Maybe we only care about the retries and not so much about the timeout threshold, e.g 100s timeout seems long when that request itself might just be botched, and we only care about retrying it. 

Hardhat has this as an explicit option so it makes sense for Anvil to also have it as well, as everyone's environments/needs are different.

agreed, will definitely add this as a config option
